p: Autophagosome formation includes three steps: initiation, nucleation, and expansion. The first step in formation of autophagosome is at the phagophore assembly site (PAS) (isolation membrane) where proteins of the unc-51 like autophagy activating kinase 1 (ULK1) complex combine in order to begin autophagosome formation [ 86]. In the next stage (nucleation), activated ULK complex targets a class III PI3K complex to contribute to the production of a PI3K pool that is specific to autophagosomes [ 87]. In the next step, phosphatidylinositol (PI) 3-phosphate (PI3P)-enriched membrane domains (omegasomes) are formed which then expand to form the double-membrane autophagosome [ 88]. In the final stage, the autophagosome membrane recruits the ATG12–ATG5–ATG16 complex, which facilitates microtubule-associated protein 1 light chain 3 (MAP1LC3; LC3) lipidation with phosphatidylethanolamine (PE). The isolation membrane expansion is dependent on LC3 (the mammalian homolog of yeast ATG8). Deacetylation of LC3 and cytosolic translocation is essential for its lipidation during starvation-induced autophagy [ 89].
